channel.title: TuxRadar Linux Podcast (mp3)
channel.copyright: Released under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported Licence
channel.description: The original five series of the Tux Radar podcast
channel.itunes:author: Tux Radar
channel.itunes:summary: A now defunct podcast. Check out the Bug Report (https://bugreport.com) for Andrew, Ben, Graham and Mike's latest podcast

item.title: Season 5 Episode 17
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Mike Saunders and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Like the legend of the phoenix
item.description: In this episode: The founder of Puppy Linux retires. SteamOS has been announced by Valve and CyanogenMod gets $7m in funding. Hear our eclectic discoveries, the sound of Tanner's brains and your own opinions in the Internet Famous Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Puppy, SteamOS, CyanogenMod, Gnome, Android, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar, ttfn

item.title: Season 5 Episode 16
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: ROT-13
item.description: In this episode: Encryption is dead, but there are lots of great games in the new Humble Indie Bundle. FreeBSD ditches GCC and Intel clashes with Ubuntu. We've got some great discoveries, we dust down the old wheel of misfortune and discuss your opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: NSA, Intel, FreeBSD, Humble Indie Bundle, Ubuntu, Canonical, Android, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 15
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Bomba Kabisa
item.description: In this episode: No more Groklaw and no Ubuntu Edge. ZTE's Firefox phone sells out quickly on eBay, and the exFAT filesystem is now open source. And as usual, we also have discoveries, challenges, brains and ballots!
item.itunes:keywords: Groklaw, Ubuntu Edge, Firefox, Samsung, exFAT, Ubuntu, Canonical, Android, Firefox, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 14
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Daft Punk
item.description: In this episode: Tor (plus a Firefox vulnerability) has been compromised. Canonical's Ubuntu Edge compaign has some way to go (but they've just added a lower priced tier). And Jean-Baptiste Queru is leaving the Android Open Source Project. We've got some great discoveries, Ben succeeds brilliantly in our challenge, and there's an awesome Open Ballot too.
item.itunes:keywords: Tor, Ubunut Edge, Ubuntu, Canonical, Android, Firefox, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 13
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Chris Thornett
item.itunes:subtitle: Edgy Ubuntu
item.description: In this episode: Canonical attempts to crowdfund its own cutting-edge smartphone and Linus Torvalds gets into an argument on the kernel mailing list. We also have some nice discoveries, a couple of great Brains submissions and the ever-awesome Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Linus, Ubunut Edge, Ubuntu, Canonical, Gnome, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 12
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: The Sound of Music
item.description: In this episode: Cryptocat breaks. LXDE moves to Qt. Firefox phones are now available. Lubuntu and Kubuntu aren't going to Mir. Fedora 19 is out and Samsung is sponsoring a $4m developer challenge. We've got discoveries, an Open Ballot, and a rather surreal music listening section.
item.itunes:keywords: Cryptocat, LXDE, Qt, Firefox phone, Lubuntu, Kubuntu, Fedora, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 11
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Hong Kong Phooey
item.description: In this episode: Where in the world is Edward Snowdon? Richard Stallman is now internet famous. Adobe and Citrix open source their stuff. Canonical's Ubuntu Phone now has its own club. Eben Upton gets a Silver Medal and the Ouya games console is available now. Hear our discoveries, the sound of people's brains, and your own mindvoices in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: NSA, Richard Stallman, Ubuntu, Raspberry Pi, Adobe, Citrix, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 10
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Chris Thornett
item.itunes:subtitle: PRISM schism
item.description: In this episode: It looks like Rockwell was right - somebody was watching him (and us). There's a great new Raspberry Pi installer and the President of the US promises action against patent trolls. Ubuntu's 'bug one' has been fixed and the EFF objects to DRM in HTML 5. As ever, hear our discoveries and your opinions in this epic length podcast.
item.itunes:keywords: Prism, NSA, Ubuntu, Raspberry Pi, EFF, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 9
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison, Chris Thornett
item.itunes:subtitle: Araminta Station
item.description: In this episode: Mint 15 is here! There's a new Fedora-based respin for the Raspberry Pi. The city of Munich and the country of Australia make great progress in moving towards open source and there's a new Humble Bundle. Hear our discoveries and your own Open Ballot opinions, plus, we welcome a new member to the team.
item.itunes:keywords: Mint, Ubuntu, Fedora, Raspberry Pi, BitTorrent, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 8
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Final Frontier + 1
item.description: In this episode: There's a critical vulnerability in the kernel. But relax, it's been fixed. The International Space Station is switching from Windows to Debian. But not Debian 7, which has just been released. The beginner's programming environment, Scratch 2.0, is out and the Raspberry Pi gets a super-light camera module. As always, hear our discoveries, our reports on the challenge and your own opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, kernel, ISS, Debian, Scratch, Raspberry Pi, BitTorrent, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 7
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Kernel Saunders
item.description: In this episode: Firefox OS phones go on sale and promptly sell out. Ubuntu 13.04 has been released. There's a new alternative to Dropbox from BitTorrent, although its licencing isn't yet clear and the BeagleBone Black is slightly cheaper than a Raspberry Pi. Hear our particularly good discoveries, our report on last episode's KDE challenge and your own opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, BeagleBone, Raspberry Pi, BitTorrent, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 6
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: The Sultans Played Creole
item.description: In this episode: We've got oodles of Google news, Nvidia's new Optimus driver, Dell selling Ubuntu games PCs and our own discoveries. Plus a new podcast challenge and the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, Nvidia, Ubuntu, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 5
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: SS Nostromo
item.description: In this episode: Samsung laptops have been fixed. OpenShot launches a Kickstarter campaign. Canonical courts Chinese officials and Ubuntu gets closer to a rolling release. Hear our suprisingly good discoveries, our woeful excuse for the lack of a live episode and your own questions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Samsung, Ubuntu, China, Canonical, Oscilloscopes, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 4
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Muphry's Law
item.description: In this episode: OpenSUSE 12.3 is out, Red Hat takes ownership of Java 6, SecureBoot is coming to FreeBSD and Ubuntu ditches Wayland for Mir. We report back on our challenge from a couple of episodes ago, come up with a new challenge, and discuss IT education in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: OpenSUSE, Ubuntu, Canonical, FreeBSD, Raspberry Pi, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 3
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Burgess Meredith
item.description: In this episode: Canonical launches Ubuntu Touch for tablets. Steam has been officially released for Linux. LG has bought WebOS for its televisions. Tizen SDK 2.0 has been released and Mozilla says there's plenty of interest in its Firefox OS. Hear our discoveries and the interim results of our challenge, plus your own opinions in our internet famous Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Cannonical, Ubuntu Touch, WebOS, LG, Steam, Mozilla, Firefox, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 2
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Boybands
item.description: In this episode: KDE 4.10 has been released and includes lots of Qt Quick enhancements. Ubuntu Phones are going to be available in October. Samsung laptops are breaking after a Linux installation and the 'Model A' Raspberry Pi is now available. Hear our discoveries, your own opinions in our Open Ballot and our brand new old section, Challenge Us!
item.itunes:keywords: Cannonical, Ubuntu, Fedora, KDE, Raspberry Pi, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 5 Episode 1
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Megaconz
item.description: In this episode: Canonical is to launch a phone. Fedora 18 has been released. Friends of Gnome are looking for money and Valve is to make a Linux-powered games console. Hear our first discoveries of 2013 and how you'd like the podcast to improve in season 5.
item.itunes:keywords: Cannonical, Ubuntu, Fedora, Valve, Steam Box, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 24
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Merry Christmas!
item.description: In this episode: Samba 4 and Linux 3.7 have been released. Raspberry Pi is auctioning off new models. Humble Bundle had a THQ special without Linux support, and THQ has since filed for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy. Valve's Steam console has been confirmed and the Linux Steam client is now an open beta.The Internet remains free but UK Pirate Party forced to shut their proxy server after pressure from BPI, and the Snooper's Charter is now uncharted. All this plus our discoveries, your brains, and the internet famous Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, Samsung, Humble Bundle, THQ, Raspberry Pi, Steam, Valve, Ubuntu, Canonical, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 23
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Papa Mau
item.description: In this episode: The UN wants to control the internets. Fedora 18 adds Mate and Cinnamon. Matthew Garrett creates a way to boot Linux from UEFI Windows 8 machines. There's lots more Apple/Samsung shenanigans and a Linux-powered autonomous boat swims almost 17000 kms to Australia. We discover things, rant about things, and listen to your opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, HTC, Mint, Red Hat, Samsung, NASA, UN, UEFI, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 22
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Happy Thanksgiving
item.description: In this episode: Linux Mint 14 has been released. Planet KDE does awesome work. There's an OpenStreetMap map-a-thon. Australia's government is TLD-shy. Red Hat invests in MongoDB, there may be life on Mars. Apple will have to reveal how much HTC is paying it, and the UEFI saga is turning nasty. Hear our non-audio related discoveries, and your own brains and opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, HTC, Mint, Red Hat, Australia, Microsoft, NASA, Linux, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 21
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Sylvia
item.description: In this episode: HP becomes a platinum member of Linux Foundation. Microsoft sponsors LinuxCon Europe. Steam for Linux Launched. FreeBSD now officially Clang-based. Android turns 5. Enlightenment 17 enters Alpha. Lots of bad news for Apple. UK government redefines open standard and the ext4 bug has been patched (well ... sort of). We've also got lots of discoveries, a single rant and the open ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, ext4, Ubuntu, LinuxCon, HP, Microsoft, E17, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 20
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Two cows and a house
item.description: In this episode: Raspberry Pi is nearly open source. Wayland 1.0 and Ubuntu 12.10 are here. Mandriva is being reborn, again. Goophone-mini has been announced and Apple apologises to Samsung over its patent dispute. Americans can jailbreak their phones, but they can no longer unlock them. There's a problem with the ext4, and Amazon remotely wipes a customer's Kindle. Plus: hear the best ever Speak your Brains, our own discoveries and your own opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, Samsung, ext4, Ubuntu, Amazon, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 19
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Vive la France
item.description: In this episode: More jury confusion on the Apple vs. Samsung case. Blue Systems sponsors KWin. Linux kernel 3.6 is out, and 3.7 is going to be ARM-unified. You can now shutdown Gnome 3.6 and the French adore le logiciel libre. Plus, hear our discoveries, our rants and raves, and your own opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, kernel, KDE, Samsung, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 18
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza and Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Happy Birthday GNU
item.description: Ubuntu embeds Amazon search results into its local search. There's a massive Android vulnerability. Cinnamon 1.6 is out and Nvidia is going to open up its Tegra GPU documentation. Hear our discoveries and listen to the internet famous, Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, Android, Samsung, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 17
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: World Exclusive
item.description: In this episode: OpenSUSE 12.2 has been released, the Raspberry Pi is now made on the UK, Michael Meeks dives into the on-going Linux desktop discussions and Alan Turing is immortalised with his own Monopoly set. Discover our discoveries and hear why our 'open ballot' is the second hit in a Google search for 'open ballot'.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, OpenSUSE, desktop, Raspberry Pi, hacking, Linux

item.title: Season 4 Episode 16
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Patent orgy
item.description: In this episode: Apple vs. Samsung woes. Mageia is getting very popular. Twitter joins the Linux Foundation and Miguel de Icaza thinks OS X killed the Linux desktop. Share in the wonder of our discoveries, hear Andrew and Graham rant and rave and feel part of the team in Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Apple, Samsung, OS X, patents, Linux

item.title: Season 4 Episode 15
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Ben Everard, Gary Walker
item.itunes:subtitle: And then there were three
item.description: In this episode: Abandoned by Jon, Graham and Effy, three brave LXFers soldier on. We discuss CDE, Debian, XFCE, iCloud, the Ubuntu App Showdown and the Liberated Pixel Cup. We discover Linux Mint 13, dd, the Cask Corner, and Stella (the distro, not the beer). We Get upset about the British transport system and Ubuntu's package management, and happy about Rasbian's setup tool. And we get your views on whether Linux can corner the gaming market. Oh, and apologies for the audio quality: there were some gremlins in the recording software. Normal service will be resumed in a fortnight.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, CDE, XFCE, iCloud, Linux

item.title: Season 4 Episode 14
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Ben Everard, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Silver lining
item.description: In this episode: There's a problem with Nvidia's proprietary graphics drivers and it looks like Nokia might sell its interest in the Qt toolkit. There's another Linux audio framework on the horizon and we meet Linus Torvalds. Share in our discoveries, listen to fellow listeners' brains and hear your own opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Nvidia, Nokia, Qt, Linux, Linus, Portland, OSCON

item.title: Season 4 Episode 13
item.itunes:author: Gary Walker, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Ben Everard and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Uncle Effy
item.description: In this episode: Steam'd Penguins. New hope for MeeGo. Buy loads of Raspberry Pis. Redphone is now open source. Project Sputnik has entered beta. Ouya open source console breaks Kickstarter records. Hear our on topic discoveries, your own opinions in the Open Ballot and some ranting and raving.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Wine, Valve, Steam, Raspberry, Ouya

item.title: Season 4 Episode 12
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Higgs Boson
item.description: In this episode: The Higgs Boson has been discovered-ish. An extra nano second has wreaked havoc on Linux servers. Diablo III runs on Wine. Ubuntu drops Grub 2 over secure boot worries, and your comments from the last podcast are internet famous. Hear our better-than-average discoveries and your own opinions, in their original format, in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Higgs Boson, Ubuntu, Grub, Blizzard, Wine, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 11
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Shineness
item.description: In this episode: Linus doesn't like Nvidia. The Unity 4 games engine is coming to Linux. There's an Ubuntu app developer contest and Microsoft unveils surface computers and Windows phone 8. Hear our discoveries then your own opinions in the Speak your Brains section. And our Open Ballot is now the 4th result in Google when you search for 'open ballot'.
item.itunes:keywords: Nvidia, Linus Torvalds, Ubuntu, Unity3D, Microsoft, Surface, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 10
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Everybody loves Linus
item.description: In this episode: Two of the biggest distributions of the year have been released - Fedora 17 and Mint 13. Red Hat finds a solution to the UEFI problem with Windows 8 certified hardware, and both Steam and Carmageddon Reincarnation are coming to Linux. We've got more discoveries, a great Speak Your Brains section and one of the best Open Ballots for weeks.
item.itunes:keywords: Fedora, Red Hat, Mint, Steam, Google, Chrome, Microsoft, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 9
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Minted
item.description: In this episode: Linux Mint 13 has been released. Chrome becomes the number one web browser (kinda). Google beats Oracle. Mandriva now belongs to you. KDE has announced a new Partner Network and there's going to be a new rival to the Raspberry Pi. Share in our discoveries, speak your brains and hear your opinions in our Open Ballot, a section which has very little to do with ballots these days.
item.itunes:keywords: Mint, Google, Chrome, Oracle, Mandriva, VIA, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 8
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Odysseus Returns
item.description: In this episode: Electronic Arts and Canonical make an important announcement. Microsoft won't allow Firefox on Windows RT. Ubuntu will ship on 5% of PCs worldwide next year and Linux Format magazine gets into the news. As ever, share our discoveries, hear our rants and raves and listen to your own opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, Microsoft, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 7
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: UCubed
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu 12.04 LTS has been released. Steam might be coming to Linux again. Google Drive should be on Linux, but isn't. And Linus wins the Millenium Technology Prize. Hear our compressed discoveries and your own opinions in both the Open Ballot and Speak Your Brains sections.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, Android, Google, Linus, Microsoft, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 6
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Skeleton Crew
item.description: In this episode: Kubuntu has a new sponsor. Many OS X users are suffering from a trojan called Flashback. The awesome Raspberry Pi has passed CE testing. Microsoft is now a significant contributor to the Linux kernel. There's a major update to MythTV, Android has been merged with the Linux kernel 3.3 and the UK government wants unprecedented access to your online life. As ever, share our discoveries and hear your own opinions in the fabulous Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Kubuntu, MythTV, Android, Raspberry Pi, Microsoft, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 5
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts and Gary Walker
item.itunes:subtitle: Penguin Jazz Cafe
item.description: In this episode: Even more Raspberry Pi delay. Munich saves the euro by switching to Linux. Vivaldi has sold out, Gnome 3.4 has been released and Microsoft releases lots of ASP stuff under the Apache 2.0 licence. Share our discoveries, hear us rant and rave and study into your own opinions in the internet famous, Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Raspberry Pi, Munich, Gnome, Microsoft, Linux Format, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 4 Episode 4
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts and Gary Walker
item.itunes:subtitle: Perpetual Bond
item.description: In this episode: The Arch distribution is ten years old! Ubuntu adoption has overtaken RHEL, according to Mark Shuttleworth. Raspberry Pi faces further delays and nVidia joins the Linux Foundation. Hear our discoveries - including a new addition - and hear your own views in our famous Speak Your Brains and Open Ballot sections.
item.itunes:keywords: Arch, Ubuntu, Canonical, Raspberri Pi, nVidia, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 4 Episode 3
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: The Guild of Linux Podcasters
item.description: In this episode: Raspberry Pi is out, and sold out. Mozilla kicks Boot to Gecko into game. OpenSUSE annoys Linus Torvalds and Canonical has announced a smartphone/PC mashup. Learn about Cheetahs, secret smartphones and your own opinions in our infamous Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, SUSE, Raspberri Pi, CheetahsFirefox, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 4 Episode 2
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Lilley's Pear and Apple Cider
item.description: In this episode: XBMC Eden is nearly out. There's a new Gnome applications design guide. Raspberry Pi has announced a manufacturing date. Canonical announce the Ubuntu Enterprise Remix and ends support for Kubuntu. Linux Foundation says Linux jobs are on the up and LibreOffice 3.5 is out. Also, hear the sound of our discoveries, a listener's submission for 'Speak your Brains' and the rumble of a battle in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, SUSE, Raspberri Pi, Westgate Pug, KDE, Plasma, Firefox, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 4 Episode 1
item.itunes:author: Ben Everard, Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison and Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Freaky Friday
item.description: In this episode: We turn our news section into a lightening news section and briefly discuss Ubuntu, Red Hat, Plasma Active, Tizen, GKH, Samsung and Firefox. Hear our discoveries from the last couple of months, our rants and raves and your own awesome opinions in our internet famous Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Red Hat, Plasma, Firefox, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 24
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts and Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Live from the WestGate Pub
item.description: In this episode: HP gives WebOS to the world, and Chrome is more secure than Firefox (according to Google). We discover an 80s games magazine, a Linux games client, a museum in Mexico and Mint's upgrade policy. Hear your views in our Open Ballot , plus, Mike joins us, and Effy has made another video!
item.itunes:keywords: Chrome, Firefox, Mint, Android, Mexico, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 23
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Extra Strong Mint
item.description: In this episode: Linux Mint 12 has been released and it includes an innovative new take on Gnome Shell. Also, lots of smartphones could be running a rootkit-like piece of software and we discover things, read your views and discuss whether a Computer Science degree is worth the investment.
item.itunes:keywords: Unity, Mint, Android, Gnome Linux Format, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 22
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Live from Mission Burrito
item.description: In this episode: Fedora 16 has been released, Ubuntu may not include Banshee next time, and Mint may have found a way to upgrade to Gnome 3.2. Hear our discoveries and your opinions, and enjoy the lunchtime ambiance of an authentic Mexican restaurant.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, Fedora, WebOS, Linux Format, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 21
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Vienna Calling
item.description: In this episode: Mark Shuttleworth wants Ubuntu to be everywhere within the next couple of years, and we cover Nokia's developers' conference from last week. Listen to our awesome discoveries, share our joy and mirth in the new section and hear your own opinions in the wonderful Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, Nokia, Qt, Android, Linux Format, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 20
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Whisky Galore
item.description: In this episode:Ubuntu 11.10 has been released and includes lots of innovation and fixes. LibreOffice is coming to both a web browser and Android device near you, and co-founder of UNIX, Dennis Ritchie, has died. Share in the joy of our discoveries, hear us rant and rave, and listen to your own opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, UNIX, LibreOffice, Linux Format, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 19
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Best Laid Schemes
item.description: In this episode: Canonical launches an app developer portal and there's a new mobile Linux initiative. We create a whole new section of the podcast, discover lots of things and discuss whether secure booting will hinder Linux adoption.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Canonical, Microsoft, UEFI, Linux Format, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 18
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Maybe Baby
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu should move to a monthly release, according to Scott Remnant. Bruce Perrens has come up with a new scheme for copyright ownership and Linux Format turns 150. Hear how successful we are at discovering things, building mesh networks and thinking up excuses.
item.itunes:keywords: Unity, Ubuntu, Perens, Linux Format, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 17
item.itunes:author: Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: And Then There Were Three
item.description: In this episode: Against all odds, Mandriva 2011 has been released while HP looks set to drop WebOS and its TouchPad tablet. We discover things, provide an update on our wireless mesh project and listen to your opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Mandriva, HP, Mozilla, Linus, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 16
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Linux Surprise
item.description: In this episode: Google spends $12.5 billion acquiring Motorola's smart phone division. Linus switches from Gnome to Xfce and KDE 5 development is about to start. We discover things, draw our own boxes, and listen to your views in the open ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Mozilla, Google, Motorola, Linus, KDE, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 15
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Batting for freedom
item.description: In this episode: KDE 4.7 has been released and it's awesome. Microsoft and SUSE reaffirm their their patent vows and Chrome is now the most popular browser in the UK. We discover some cool things, write our own Linux jingles and discuss what Linux might look like in ten years.
item.itunes:keywords: Microsoft, SUSE, Chrome, Google, KDE, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 14
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Live from Andrew's House
item.description: In this episode: Apple asserts its patents against HTC. CentOS 6 has been released while GNU Hurd might be ready for the next Debian. Listen to our discoveries and your opinions, and share our joy in finally managing to complete a You Dare Us challenge.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, HTC, CentOS, Google, Hurd, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 13
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Wizard of OS
item.description: In this episode: Sabayon 6 has been released, Google launches a new social network and Red Hat is doing well. Share in our discoveries, hear our ideas for a 'You Dare Us' replacement and you tackle Firefox version numbers in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Sabayon, Fedora, Red Hat, Google, Firefox, Gnome Shell, Unity, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 12
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Air Lacquer
item.description: In this episode: Chrome might replace Firefox in future versions of Ubuntu. Fedora 16 will make Btrfs the default filesystem. Firefox 5 has been released and Adobe is dropping Linux desktop support for Air. Share our cool discoveries from the last two weeks, hear how we fared installing Linux whilst blindfolded and we discuss your opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Btrfs, Fedora, Ubuntu, Firefox, Adobe, Air, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 11
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Come back Mike!
item.description: In this episode: Mageia 1.0 has been released while ASUS promises three new netbooks running Linux. Meanwhile, back in California, Oracle tries to give OpenOffice.org to the Apache Foundation and you can hear some of our best discoveries, our worst challenge result, and your own opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Bugs, Mageia, Oracle, Unity, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 10
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Lovelock and load
item.description: In this episode: Fedora 15 has arrived and the next release of the kernel may be called 3.0. We discover some interesting things, comment on the awesome IRC session we all joined, come up with an adopt-a-project plan and ask, should Gnome become Linux-only?
item.itunes:keywords: Fedora, MeeGo, IRC, kernel, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 9
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory,Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Final Frontier
item.description: In this episode: David Braben creates a low-cost Linux machine. Matt Zimmerman leaves Canonical while Mark Shuttleworth wants 200 million Ubuntu users within 4 years. Discover our discoveries, hear the latest conversion stories from TuxRadar and join us on IRC.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Braben, IRC, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 8
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Nutty Narwhal
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu 11.04 is here, while Oracle drops OpenOffice.org, and there's a third humble indie bundle. Discover our discoveries, hear how we fared with Gnome Shell and the results of our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Gnome, Unity, Oracle, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 7
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Jonathan Roberts, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Better late than never
item.description: In this episode: Gnome 3.0 has been released while Nokia takes back its Symbian operating system. Red Hat is approaching $1b in revenue and Groklaw is calling it a day. Share in our discoveries, hear our responses to your emails and letters and join us in welcoming a new member to the team.
item.itunes:keywords: Fedora, Gnome, Firefox, Red Hat, Groklaw, Nokia, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 6
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: A message from our sponsors
item.description: In this episode: Canonical and Gnome may benefit from some relationship counselling. GTK+ 3.2 will enable you to run Gnome apps through a web browser. The Debian Derivatives Exchange (DEX) project has launched and Firefox 4 is here. Share our discoveries, listen to our marketing slogans and hear your own opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Canonical, Gnome, Firefox, Debian, DEX, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 5
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Stallman wasn't stalling
item.description: In this episode: Gnome drops both the maximise and minimise buttons. Mark Shuttleworth admits mistakes were made over the Banshee debacle and Nokia sells most of Qt. Discover our discoveries and challenge results, and hear your own opinions in the Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Canonical, Banshee, Ubuntu, Gnome, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 4
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Qt, or not Qt?
item.description: In this episode: Microsoft and Nokia form an alliance and the GPLv3 might not be welcome on Windows Phone. Canonical gets controversial with Banshee while openSUSE and Fedora users might have to wait for Unity. Hear our discoveries, our limited success with the challenge, and your own opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Microsoft, Android, Canonical, Ubuntu, Crunchbang, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 3
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Flying Pigs
item.description: In this episode: We try to bury the news, which includes the release of Debian 6.0 and KDE 4.6, along with some Android rumours. Hear how we faired with our challenge to contribute to an open source project, and share our discoveries from the last two weeks.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, Debian, KDE, Android, Gnome, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 3 Episode 2
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Efrain Hernandez-Mendoza, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Overtaking Manoeuvres
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu is going to bundle Qt libraries with its base install. Google will no longer bundle H.264 with Chrome and Firefox 4 will only have limited hardware acceleration. Share our discoveries, try XFCE, and listen to your own conversion stories in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Canonical, Qt, XFCE, Android, KDE, TuxRadar, Linux, LibreOffice

item.title: Season 3 Episode 1
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Overtaking Manoeuvres
item.description: In this episode: Firefox overtakes Internet Explorer in Europe while Android overtakes iPhone in the US, and TransGaming transforms Cedega into the GameTree Developer Program. Discover our new section and hear your own opinions in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Android, Apple, KDE, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 2 Episode 24
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Don't look back in anger
item.description: In this episode: We take a look back at our favourite news stories, discoveries, dares and ballots from the previous 23 episodes and ask you to choose your biggest Linux-related events from 2010.
item.itunes:keywords: KDE, Oracle, Google, Java, Android, Gnome, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 2 Episode 23
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Join Us!
item.description: In this episode: The KDE team rebrands KOffice into the Calligra Suite. OpenSUSE unveils a rolling release version of its distribution and Google's Chrome OS has been delayed until next year. This time, we remember our discoveries, and ask whether next year might really be the year of Linux on the desktop.
item.itunes:keywords: KDE, Calligra, TuxRadar, OpenSUSE, Google, Chrome, Desktop

item.title: Season 2 Episode 22
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Hudzilla Returns
item.description: In this episode: Attachmate Corporation pays $2.2 billion for Novell. A Linux kernel patch dramatically improves desktop performance, while Fedora considers a move to Wayland. We ask whether a lack of blockbuster games is holding Linux back, and hear us completely forget discovery of the fortnight.
item.itunes:keywords: Novell, Attachmate, Microsoft, TuxRadar, Canonical, Ubuntu, Nokia, Wayland, Symbian

item.title: Season 2 Episode 21
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: The one without Paul
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu may ditch the X Window system for Wayland, Fedora 14 has been released and Nokia takes Symbian back from the Symbian Foundation. Share our fortnight's discoveries and hear whether we think Qt and KDE should merge APIs.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Canonical, Ubuntu, Nokia, Wayland, Symbian

item.title: Season 2 Episode 20
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Longer than expected
item.description: In this episode: The London Stock Exchange is super fast, thanks to Linux, while Android celebrates its 100,000th app submission. We discover things and talk about tiling window managers, while our listeners talk about Ubuntu's Unity.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Android, LSE, Ubuntu, Canonical, Unity, Nokia

item.title: Season 2 Episode 19
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Welcome to the Jungle
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu 10.10 has been released, and Microsoft attacks OpenOffice.org with a video. Discover our all-new challenge for the next episode, and we judge the level of anticipation for Panasonic's Jungle.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Jungle, Ubuntu, Panasonic, Microsoft, OpenOffice

item.title: Season 2 Episode 18
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Asbestos Gloves
item.description: In this episode: Both Mandriva and OpenOffice.org have been forked, while Microsoft sues Motorola for bits of Android. Try the results of our text adventure challenge and hear your own comments in our Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Linux, flame, PC Plus, Mandriva, LibreOffice, Microsoft, Motorola, Android

item.title: Season 2 Episode 17
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: 88 Miles Per Hour
item.description: In this episode: We each predict a news story that may or may not have happened over the last seven days. Play the final results of our 'build a game' challenge, and we ask, is it finally time to do away with the command-line?
item.itunes:keywords: TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 2 Episode 16
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Mike May Vary
item.description: In this episode: Sony was legally allowed to remove the 'Other OS' feature from the Playstation 3, according to Australian lamakers. Glibc is now really free and KSplice gets into Fedora. We report back from the mid-point of our games development challenge, and ask, what's your favourite Linux improvement?
item.itunes:keywords: Sony, Microsoft, Playstation, KSplice, Fedora, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 2 Episode 15
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Gnaborretni
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu 10.10 is going to add gesture support and 11.04 is going to be called the Natty Narwhal. Debian 6.0 has been feature frozen while Oracle sets its sights on Google. Discover how we fared with our Nethack challenge, and how we filled the Open Ballot section without an Open Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Canonical, Ubuntu, KDE, Gnome, Oracle, Sun, TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 2 Episode 14
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: KDelay
item.description: In this episode: Gnome 3.0 has been delayed while the Gnome team releases its first census results. KDE 4.5 should be here, and Mark Shuttleworth dislikes tribalism. Discover our new 'You Dare Us' challenge, and we reveal our discoveries from the last two weeks. Finally, hear us discuss one of the most compelling Open Ballots in living memory.
item.itunes:keywords: Gnome, KDE, OpenSUSE, Red Hat, Canonical, Novell, Meego TuxRadar, Linux

item.title: Season 2 Episode 13
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: Positivity
item.description: In this episode: A SCO representative finally reveals some of the Linux code SCO had a problem with and OpenSUSE 11.3 is here. Listen to the results of our new challenge, and we ask whether the likes of Red Hat, Novell and Canonical contribute enough back to the community.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, SCO, OpenSUSE, Red Hat, Canonical, Novell, TuxRadar, Python

item.title: Season 2 Episode 12
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison
item.itunes:subtitle: The shortest episode, ever.
item.description: In this episode: The first Mozilla 4 beta is here while Nokia is moving rapidly forward with MeeGo for mobiles. We report back on our You Dare Us challenge and hear Paul tackle Python.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, Nokia, Linux, TuxRadar, Python

item.title: Season 2 Episode 11
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: The one without Andrew, mostly.
item.description: In this episode: Google releases its own command-line tool, Ubuntu drops F-Spot, and has anyone seen Mandriva? Listen to the results of our haiku challenge, and we ask, do you use open source software for freedom or function?
item.itunes:keywords: Google, Ubuntu, Mandriva, Apple, Linux, TuxRadar, Unity

item.title: Season 2 Episode 10
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Japanese giant flying squirrel
item.description: In this episode: Fedora 13 is out. Google drops the Windows option for new staff and yet Windows is still doing well as a server. Discover how we fared with a minority distribution and we tout our ideas on how Linux devices can beat Apple's iPad.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, iPad, Microsoft, Apple, Ubuntu, Android, Linux, TuxRadar, Unity

item.title: Season 2 Episode 9
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Google Gaggle
item.description: In this episode: We discuses the three big Linux-related announcements from Google. We present our amazing discoveries from the last fortnight and ask whether anyone is excited by the HP Slate.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, iPad, Apple, Ubuntu, Android, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 8
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Humble Bumble
item.description: In this episode: Mandriva is up for sale while Android phones are outselling iPhones in the USA. Judge our TuxRadar content challenge and we ask, should distros license codecs?
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Android, Mandriva, iPhone, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 7
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Passive Electioneering
item.description: In this episode: Lucid Lynx, Ubuntu 10.04, is here! And Valve might be porting Steam to Linux. Discover how we coped with Z shell and what we think is the biggest threat to Linux.
item.itunes:keywords: Ubuntu, Lynx, Valve, Steam, Chrome, zsh, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 6
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Pink Ponies, naturally
item.description: In this episode: The Android-based WePad takes on the mighty Apple iPad while Nokia and Intel launch MeeGo. Hear the results of our music-making challenge and ask yourselves, is Linux sexy?
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, iPad, WePad, Android, Ubuntu, MeeGo, Nokia, Intel, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 5
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: April Fools
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu switches to base 10, Novell fights takeover while Sony removes Linux support from its older Playstation 3 consoles. We reveal how little we've used Emacs and ask whether Wikipedia should use open codecs.
item.itunes:keywords: Novell, Sony, PS3, Emacs, Theora, Ubuntu, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 4
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Penguins Are Doing Time
item.description: In this episode: Gnome's Guadec and KDE's Akademy are getting back together in 2011 and are looking for a venue, while Canonical unveils a major rebranding for Ubuntu 10.04. We reveal which presenter had the most SUSE Studio downloads and report back on our time spent with Ubuntu 4.10.
item.itunes:keywords: Gnome, KDE, Guadec, Akademy, Canonical, Ubuntu, FSF, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 3
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: SUSE SUSE Studio
item.description: In this episode: Version 2.6.33 of the Linux kernel is here and it includes a new 3D accelerated Nvidia graphics driver. Canonical's online music store will only provide MP3 files, and Apple sues HTC. We report back on our experiences with SUSE Studio and answer our critics in the Closed Ballot.
item.itunes:keywords: Apple, HTC, Novell, SUSE, SUSEStudio, Canonical, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 2
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Badger Dog
item.description: In this episode: Nokia and Intel combine Maemo with Moblin to create MeeGo. OpenOffice.org 3.2 is here, and it's fast. We report back on our experiences while avoiding the command line and ask whether we'll ever use KDE 4.4.
item.itunes:keywords: Intel, Nokia, Maemo, Moblin, MeeGoo, OpenOffice.org, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 2 Episode 1
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Oleophobia
item.description: In this episode: Three quarters of the Linux kernel code is written by developers being paid to do so and Facebook transforms PHP performance. We promise to give up the command line for two weeks and ask whether Ubuntu is wrong to switch the default search engine in Firefox from Google to Yahoo. Plus, we introduce two new sections.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, Canonical, Apple, Linux, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 1 Episode 25
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Dreaming Androids
item.description: In this episode: Google releases the Nexus One and Mark Shuttleworth has announced he's going to relinquish control of Canonical. Freescale unveils a Linux touch tablet and we ask whether 2010 could really, honestly, be the year of Linux on the desktop.
item.itunes:keywords: Google, Canonical, Freescale, Android, Nexus, TuxRadar

item.title: Season 1 Episode 24
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Linux Mint
item.description: In this episode: The Gnome community considers dropping GNU, while a Gnome screensaver is found to contain malware. We trawl through our favourite TuxRadar comments of the year and ask whether it's good to sue for GPL violations.
item.itunes:keywords: Gnome, Gnome, Gnome, TuxRadar, ThinkGeek

item.title: Season 1 Episode 23
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Chromium Carousal
item.description: In this episode: The Linux version of Google's Chrome browser is now officially in beta and Linux netbook share appears to be growing. Nokia releases Qt 4.6 and we ask whether Linux documentation could be improved and is Google's Chrome operating system a good thing?
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Google, Chrome, Nokia, Qt, Gnome

item.title: Season 1 Episode 22
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: The Sound of Fail
item.description: In this episode: Google releases the source code to its new operating system, Chrome OS. The Fedora 12 distribution makes its way onto the mirrors and The Gimp is too powerful and too complex for Ubuntu 10.04. We present the results of our two-week Bing research project and ask whether we'd switch to Bing if it was the only place to find News Corp. coverage.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Google, Chrome, Fedora, Ubuntu, Bing

item.title: Season 1 Episode 21
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Mammoth Mammoth
item.description: In this episode: Firefox turns 5, Microsoft allegedly borrows some GPL code and the Fat Elf is no more. We talk about what our perfect Linux distribution would look like and ask whether everyone should be compelled to contribute to free software projects.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Canonical, Ubuntu, Windows, GPL, Firefox

item.title: Season 1 Episode 20
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Manky Monkey
item.description: In this episode: Canonical's shiny new distro, Ubuntu 9.10, is released. We talk about what's new and what's old, review a version of Ubuntu each, discuss what we love and loathe and set our minds on the future with Lucid Lynx.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Canonical, Ubuntu, Karmic, Koala

item.title: Season 1 Episode 19
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: A Hero's Welcome
item.description: In this episode: Linux is reported to be safer for online banking and international stock exchanges than Microsoft Windows, we reveal our personal geek heroes and our Open Ballot asks whether we should embrace Microsoft's open source work.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Microsoft, Debian, FreeBSD, Linus, Torvalds

item.title: Season 1 Episode 18
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Linux Convicts
item.description: In this episode: We talk about the recent Linux conferences we've attended, the final versions of both Moblin 2.0 and Gnome 2.28 and discuss whether Linux is bloated. Our Open Ballot asks 'Are distro release cycles too short?' and Andrew finds a surprisingly practical 'Discovery of the Fortnight'.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Novell, LinuxCon, OSCON, Intel, Moblin, OpenSUSE, Linus, Torvalds

item.title: Season 1 Episode 17
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Escape from Targ
item.description: In this episode: The first Linux botnet has been detected, version 2.6.31 of the Linux kernel has been released and the Haiku project announces the availability of Alpha 1 of its BeOS-like operating system. We discuss Novell's expensive foray into iPhone development with its MonoTouch SDK and we ask whether we should focus on other Unixes alongside Linux.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Novell, botnet, MonoTouch, iPhone, Unix

item.title: Season 1 Episode 16
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: The Shrieking Sister
item.description: In this episode: Nokia announces a new Linux handset, Sony drops Linux support from its new Playstation 3 console and Google creates a 64-bit version of its Chrome browser. Listen to the results of our two weeks with text-mode challenge and we ask whether we should be more zealous when promoting Linux and open source.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Nokia, Microsoft, KDE, Bing, Sony, Google

item.title: Season 1 Episode 15
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: PodKastigation
item.description: In this episode: There was a hole in the kernel for eight years. Dell announces that its Linux netbook returns are a non-issue and we look at Ubuntu One. We report on our two weeks with the KDE desktop and our open ballot asks whether open source licences should be viral.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Dell, Ubuntu, KDE, GPL, BSD, Apache

item.title: Season 1 Episode 14
item.itunes:author: Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Bob Moss, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Tron with Ponies
item.description: In this episode: SUSE Studio is out; Debian adpots timed releases, should we be giving coverage to companies who don't support Linux and should geeks prefer Free internet services over free internet services?
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Novell, SUSE, Debian, Twitter, Identica

item.title: Season 1 Episode 13
item.itunes:author: Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Bob Moss, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Lion Eggs for Matt
item.description: In this episode: Google announces its own Chrome OS operating system and the Moblin project gets X Windows running with user privileges. We talk about how we got into Linux and discuss whether we think Google is becoming Microsoft.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Google, Chrome, Moblin

item.title: Season 1 Episode 12
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Mike's Song
item.description: In this episode: Mono is finally safe to use while the HTML 5 specification is causing trouble. Canonical's Design and User Experience team launch the One Hundred Paper Cuts project for their next distro release, and do version numbers really matter?
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, HTML 5, Ubuntu, Mono

item.title: Season 1 Episode 11
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: The Battle of Thorne Waste
item.description: In this episode: Android isn't as good as Windows CE on smartbooks. Debian bundles Mono, Crossover 8 is released while Opera 10 and Firefox 3.5 are nearly here. Is sound a disaster on Linux? And should geeks boycott closed platforms like the XBox 360, Playstation 3 and iPhone?
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Android, Windows CE, Jack, ALSA, Firefox

item.title: Season 1 Episode 10
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Episode X
item.description: In this episode: Unix is 40 years old, Google releases an alpha Linux version of its Chrome browser and ARM-powered laptops are spotted at Computex. Is Linux a difficult development platform and should we thin the licensing herd?
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Google, Chrome, Netbook, Arm, Pianoteq, Gloss, BleachBit

item.title: Season 1 Episode 9
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Catafalque
item.description: In this episode: Our favourite TuxRadar comments so far, how can we help convert people from Windows and a special feature on Netbooks.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Netbook, TuxRadar, Libre.fm

item.title: Season 1 Episode 8
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Wolves in the Moonlight
item.description: In this episode: OpenOffice.org 3.1 is released while Debian forks from Glibc and Mozilla considers updating the Firefox icon. In light of the imminent release of Moonlight 2, we ask whether open source development always needs to innovate, and our Open Ballot asks whether we need a standard package format.
item.itunes:keywords: Linux, Moonlight, OpenOffice, Microsoft, Firefox

item.title: Season 1 Episode 7
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Setting Sun
item.description: In this episode: Ubuntu 9.04 is here and Renai LeMay says it's as slick as Mac OS X. We also get to play with the GP2X Wiz portable games console and ponder on the announcement that Oracle is going to buy Sun Microsystems. Our open ballot asks whether we should dump OpenOffice.org.
item.itunes:keywords: linux, TuxRadar, Oracle, Sun, Ubuntu, GP2X

item.title: Season 1 Episode 6
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Monologue
item.description: In this episode: Gtk+ developers announce plans for version 3. Microsoft proclaims 96% domination of the netbook market and both Mono 2.4 and MonoDevelop 2.0 are released. Is the new Linux Spotify library a good thing and should netbook manufacturers standardise on a single distribution?
item.itunes:keywords: linux, TuxRadar, Microsoft, Gtk+, Canonical, Netbook

item.title: Season 1 Episode 5
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders, Mark Shuttleworth
item.itunes:subtitle: Space Shuttle
item.description: In this episode: We celebrate the release of Gnome 2.26 and talk about the Chromium browser. Could the Linux community have done more to capitalise on the weak take-up of Windows Vista, and how can we prepare ourselves for Windows 7? And is it a good thing to have two competing desktop environments?
item.itunes:keywords: linux, TuxRadar, Microsoft, KDE, Shuttleworth, Canonical, Ubuntu, Chromium, Gnome

item.title: Season 1 Episode 4
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: GScrot's Previous Icon
item.description: In this episode: Jim Zemlin wants a united front for netbooks, Codeweavers want DirectX 10 for Linux, has Firefox been exploited, can we help people who are new to Linux, and should proprietary software be easy to install?
item.itunes:keywords: linux, TuxRadar, Microsoft, KDE, Zemlin, Spotify, Wine, GScrot, Shutter

item.title: Season 1 Episode 3
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Irradiated Sausage
item.description: In this episode: Debian 5 and Xfce 4.6 are released, Microsoft sues TomTom, are the Creative Commons licences working, are there too many Linux distributions and did Mike really play Captain 'S' - the remake?
item.itunes:keywords: linux, debian, TuxRadar, Microsoft, creative commons, XFCE

item.title: Season 1 Episode 2
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Was that Mike or Tony Blair?
item.description: In this episode: Moonlight 1.0 is released, how will the recession affect Linux, is Ubuntu a 'good thing' and just what exactly is Slime Forest Adventure?
item.itunes:keywords: linux, qt, moonlight, silverlight, hp, cuba, TuxRadar, ubuntu, ssh-fs, slime forest, recession

item.title: Season 1 Episode 1
item.itunes:author: Andrew Gregory, Paul Hudson, Graham Morrison, Mike Saunders
item.itunes:subtitle: Jesus Jelly
item.description: In this episode: Torvalds switches to Gnome, should we encourage people to run free software on a non-free OS, and is Mono a force for good or one big anti-Microsoft Troll?
item.itunes:keywords: linux, torvalds, renoise, TuxRadar, kde, gnome, csharprepl, mypaint, mono, silverlight
